Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Situation2: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Story: I stared at the blinking panel of the old packaging machine, my mind half on the diagnostic codes and half on the text from my younger brother. He’d just messaged, upset about a comment I’d made at dinner last night. I knew I should call him, listen, and try to see things from his perspective—he always said I was too quick to judge. But the machine’s glitch was elusive, only showing up when no one was watching, and my supervisor expected a full report by the end of the shift. I could almost hear his voice: “You’re the only one who really understands these old circuits.” My brother, meanwhile, expected patience and understanding, not the distracted, short-tempered sister I’d been lately. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the hum of the factory floor and the silent weight of my brother’s disappointment. My hands hovered over the machine’s wiring, but my thoughts were with him, wrestling with the impossible task of being both the reliable repairer and the supportive sister at the same time.
